Well, I told myself I'd review the game at 100 hours. 99.9 works too! (Early Access)

Let me start by saying this is the most fun I've had on a game in YEARS! 
Think, Skyrim, Valheim, Breath of the Wild, Minecraft, and The Forest combined. No cannibals, just spooky moments.

The Positives: 
1. Co-op makes this game incredible! I can't tell you how much fun it is to play with someone who will read the lore with you in goofy voices, jump off cliffs with you randomly, and abandon you in the middle of a boss fight because they almost got one shot. Having a loot goblin friend makes it even better.
2.It's GORGEOUS!! Seriously, I can't emphasize how beautiful this game is! I run a 2080ti and I find myself on top of mountains and trees admiring the views from above or along the water admiring the reflection of the sunset more often than I play the game. OH, and the rain! The change in sound the ground makes when its wet or dry, the way it sounds inside compared to outside, and how it looks at sunset is phenomenal!
3. The game runs incredibly smooth! From fighting hordes of enemies, to jumping into a pool of water, and even how it feels to jump off of a spire and dive straight down while gliding. 
4. Farming! If you enjoy comfy cozy games like I do or you have a friend or partner who isn't combat oriented but loves to farm and decorate. Then this game is for you. I've spent a solid 10-15 hours so far (with many more to come) just designing our homes, barn, castle (Fort Kelvin in my case) and I still have more to do.
5. Crafting - Yes the farming is included in this but I want to say that this is the best crafting I've ever used in a game. It may not be as complex as minecraft with their redstone but the way you can combine and design using the voxel game system is amazing. You can create a base completely from scratch or even take over existing areas and build off of them. I HIGHLY recommend Fort Kelvin after you unlock Hannah Reed from her quest because you can rebuild the walls, buildings, and the cave system to have a nice clean fort that keeps all of your villagers in a safe area. 
6. VOXEL GAME - This brings me to my next point. You can literally destroy 99% of the areas/buildings/trees etc. There are obviously specific things that can't but this opens up ways to get around the world because of it. Can't get past a gate early game and don't have a grapple? Mine around it. Can't get into a tower because brand new? Use Altars and build stairs literally to the top (Lets game it out for example). It's a ton of fun creating basements, caves, and treehouses using this system as well. 
7. The story - I really enjoy that there is so much lore spread out in the game. It really shows the devs put a lot of time and effort into creating a world that told a story to it. The NPC's you rescue bring so much life into the game as long as you're willing to read. 

The Cons: (or in this case, needs to be worked on to improve the game) 
1. The quest system. I had to rollback my cloud in order to finish a quest, "The Morning Grind", due to me accidentally pickaxing a skeletons body that I had to interact with and remove a ring from. I think making quest related interactions invincible would fix this simple bug. Also, while playing in co-op, my partner doesn't always get the quests when I interact with certain items or lore. 
2. Combat - My biggest frustration is getting into a fight and not being able to lock onto the target I want to in an easier way. For example, if i use a wand or a bow, sometimes the lock will target the enemy in the back instead of the guy in my face stabbing me with his sword. Sometimes I want to shoot a barrel to take out a group but instead my wand targets the guy next to the barrel instead and then I lose that opportunity. Now, I've learned how to work with this, sword enemies up close, dodge/blink back and wand enemies at mid range while using my bow to blow up barrels with free aim but swapping between my weapons on my action bar isn't always the easiest in a fight. I think there should be an easier lock on system, not sure how, but I have hopes. Oh, and make a way to block with a bow because that would be realistic. 
3. HEAL CHANNEL - Please make it so i can right click or left click in order to heal others or heal myself. It's a nice cheap spell for healing and that simple change would be huge for early/mid game mages. 
4. Pets/NPC's - They LOVE to get stuck in walls or furniture! Also, is there a way to code the npcs to return to their spots when set to 0m after going to bed? I would enjoy that if so. Like they walk to their beds at night and then return back to their spots. 
5. Map - I would like to see more clarity of the different zones on the map. You learn them eventually but I think this would benefit early/mid game for people who don't explore as much. That way when they need to get supplies, they know where to go easier. 

Again, this game is one of the best I've ever played. I can't wait to sink in more hours as content continues to be released!

I picked up Enshrouded last week with a friend, and honestly, I didn’t expect to fall this hard for a game so fast. The world is absolutely beautiful and haunting at the same time—exploring the valleys, ruins, and hidden corners feels like stepping into a living fantasy painting. The survival and building systems feel intuitive but deep enough to stay interesting, and uncovering new gear makes every adventure feel rewarding.

Co-op is where this game truly shines. My friend and I have spent hours building, fighting, and wandering—sometimes with a real plan, sometimes just “let’s see what’s over that hill” vibes. Either way, it’s always fun.

And now I’m so hyped for Update 7. The water update looks gorgeous and adds exactly the kind of atmosphere and immersion the world has been teasing since day one. Seeing the devs continue to expand and refine things just makes me more confident that this game is only going to get better with time.

If you love exploration, building, and a world you can genuinely get lost in—this one’s for you.

By far one of the best voxel games I have ever played. The level of detail and love the developers pour into each update is incredible. The graphics run very well, and with the water update, now you can create creeks and gardens. While I feel there is still much to add. This, this makes me happy to play as a family game.

Honestly? It's like Skyrim, to me, on the aspect that it has vast exploration, a lot of interactivity with the world around you (minus the NPCs, they're okay on that part), skill level tree that branches out on how you want your character to turn out, and a lot of good enemies/bosses that it never gets dull.

I like the base building mode. You gather new ideas as you progress through the game, and it's really fun to see what new building blueprints come-up! Although, I don't particularly care much to be building (unless I can get some sort of blueprint on a starter house/farm of sorts, I'd be more into it. I'm lazy on crafting blocks).

My only complaint is that, when it gets dark, it sure as heck gets DARK. I'm over here having to squint my eyes, or open them wide, to not die from a pitfall, or some spawn of enemies jump scaring me. I turned up my brightness a little, so it kind of helped, but I would prefer some sort of wearable lantern/light source to help with the dark, as I can't hold a torch in one-hand and wield a weapon in the other.

Enshrouded is a great open world survival RPG.  Its one of the few in the genre along side Abiotic Factor that promotes both single player and co-op.  What I mean by this is that unlike most other games in the same genre, Enshrouded allows you to tweak the difficulty of your world, allowing you to either make it super hard or super easy.

In the world difficulty, you can choose to have a custom game difficulty selection, you can change how much damage you do and how much enemies do, the size of enemy health bar, the amount of loot that drops, how fast or slow is the production of items (speed of refining crafting materials in various crafting benches), the difficulty of the fishing minigame, and much more options.

Not only that but Enshrouded is also adding in new weapons and weapon types, like in the most recent update the devs added in 2-handed swords, where previously there were only 2-handed axes and hammers.  Enshrouded also added swimming and a brand new biome.

My only complaints/suggestions to the devs are:

1.  Please make it so that Shields do not disable/make invisible/make disappear the armour plating on the left hand of the character while wearing the Knight armour set and Warrior armour set.

2.  Can we please get some kind of weapon and shield transmog? Having armour cosmetic slots was awesome, but can we please get some for weapons and shields?  As of now I think (but don't quote me on this) that you will slowly unlock the crafting recipes for various weapons you find?  But I'm not 100% sure what causes them to unlock and not sure if it applies to all weapons.

3.  Please expand on the armour dying mechanic.  As of now it is very limited as to which armour and how you can dye your armour sets.  But it would be cool to be able to change the colour of the armour plating for melee armour.  I really wish I could change the colour of the armour plating on the Knight armour set and the Mercenary armour set.

All in all, Enshrouded is a game I 100% recommend if you like a open world survival RPG.  Its great for both solo and co-op play.  Do take note this game is in EA, so even though I did mentioned things I have issues with above, I still do love this game and hope the Devs will eventually come around to addressing the issues I've mentioned eventually.

I am a big building/survival game nerd. I'm a sucker for those titles. Often caught myself buying those risky early access titles (yikes). I've played 800h+ of Minecraft, 400h+ of No Man's Sky, 300h+ of Satisfactory, 200h+ of Valheim, 200h+ of Ark Survival Evolved, 100h+ of Rust, 100h+ Cities Skyline, name a building/survival game, I've probably spent hundreds of hours on it.

Enshrouded stands to become one of my, if not my favorite game of the lot. Here's why;

## Build

One of the best, if not the best building game. The adaptive voxel-based building system paired with the free-placement of detailed furnitures as well as the possibility to place wandering NPCs makes your build come to life. Enshrouded's great, colorful and vibrant graphics lets you enjoy your creation exactly how you imagine them. Every building can have the feeling you want, from magical greenhouses to sadistic dungeons.

## Survival

The survival aspect of the game looks a lot like Valheim. The food system is almost identical, forcing you to eat different kinds of food to get the full buffs. Although I don't play on the highest difficulty, the survival aspect of the game seems to be much more forgiving than Valheim. I have yet to spend an entire afternoon running after my dropped loot, only to die again trying to leave the damn swamp. I have yet to unlock cooking, but there is enough variety in the ingredients to lead me to believe that, combined with alchemy recipes, it will be decent and varied enough for the sake of combat and exploration.

## Combat

So far the combat is challenging and has enough depth for a survival, adventure, building game. It can feel basic if you're used to Souls-like games, Mordhau etc. but IMO it's diversified enough through various combat styles to not get boring. It's Hogwarts Legacy-level magic combined with a basic medieval RPG (so far). Grinding for rarer loot and working towards upgrading it feels meaningful and rewarding. I hope that the game continues to scale in a similar way for the entire playthrough and add more challenging end-game to encourage replayability.

## Exploration

The world is beautiful so far, and I've almost only seen forest and mountains. I have yet to leave the starter biome (the map is huge). Points of interest are an interesting blend of combat, puzzle and platformer, which keeps the gameplay varied throughout the exploration. There are few QoL Mobility equipement to craft which can make moving around more efficient and interesting. Exploration feels rewarding and pushing your expeditions too far can be deadly. You have to explore strategically and be prepared for almost anything (although I would love to see some dangerous random events added to add even more to this).

## Depth

A lot of these types of games are missing depth. They include so many different systems that they often fail to add sufficient depth to make it meaningful to even want to reach the end of their mechanics. They often present you with the same old building, crafting, cooking, fishing systems, each lacking depth and meaning to your progression. The games scales in content, but not in depth or rely in a specific gameplay aspect to justify replayability (PVP for Rust, Endless Exploration for NMS, ...), or some very obviously flawed systems make it much less rewarding. In Enshrouded case, so far, it seems to be a little bit better on that end.

All in all, if a game that balances survival, building, combat (but not hardcore) and exploration almost perfectly (in my book), you'll definitely enjoy Enshrouded.

Enshrouded is probably one of the best co-op survival action RPGs out there.

[u]Game World / Story / Quests:[/u]
The world with all its biomes is really massive, is looking beautiful, has a lot of interesting places to discover and explore and most importantly, it does not feel empty. Quests will take you to almost every location and they feel diverse enough. The Shroud also allows for different gameplay and is a clever way to control the progression, so you have to follow certain main quests, while still having a lot of freedom. The underlying story sets the general framework for the world and why you are there, but it has not too much impact. There are a TON of quests, many are optional. Depending on your playstyle, progression can be really slow.

[u]RPG / Combat / Gameplay:[/u]
The skill tree and various roles are fairly complex, with many different abilities to suit your character. Specializing and splitting up roles does give you benefits and goes well with 3-4 players. The combat system is fine, sometimes a bit to easy. Balance could be better, some abilities are almost useless, while others are mandatory to succeed. Although there are a lot of different enemy types, you rarely have to fight them differently. Boss fights are cool, but there could be more of them.
Typical RPG-elements like looting, leveling up gear, different armor sets, food-buffs are all included and mostly are implemented well.

[u]Building / Crafting:[/u]
The building system allows for extrem freedom and creativity. One of the most outstanding features, setting it apart from other games. Due to the amount of complexity it can get a bit fiddly here and there.
Farming resources can get repetetive, depending on how much you want to build. But overall the game offers a lot, if you love to build.

Pros:

- Very, very beautiful looking game, I've rarely seen a game look so good. I always said, all a game needs to look good is a lot of vegetation + good lighting, and this game perfected that.

- Combat and skills are fun and don’t really get boring.

- Base building is very detailed + you can build underground.

- A lot of biomes that look very different from each other.

- Exploring is a lot of fun until it’s not anymore (see cons).

- A lot of quests and content.

- Dungeons/Camps/Caves are a lot of fun; some of them take forever to do (in a good way).

Cons:

- Stamina! Why is stamina a thing... The map is already way too big, why limit sprinting/gliding? But the worst thing is the stamina consumption while mining or chopping trees. Just why? It serves no purpose at all. It makes no sense how combat doesn’t use stamina but everything else does. It just slows down progression for no reason at all. The only thing that’s okay is stamina while climbing & rolling. Just let me mine and farm without having to stand still for a minute to refill stamina.

- The map is way too big for the amount of content the game has. There are not enough bosses or enemy types in the game, which makes it get repetitive really quickly. You fight the same enemies over and over again in every biome. It’s always either the Shroud, Humans, Undead, or Vukah enemies, and that continues throughout the whole game.

- Exploring becomes less and less interesting the further you get into the game because the loot is randomized. You can do a Hollow Halls dungeon for an hour and get the same loot from the final chest that you get from random normal chests in the open world.

- Crafting feels weird sometimes. Why do I have to wait 10 minutes to craft something? It makes it feel like a mobile game.

- I’m playing as a Mage, and the auto-targeting with wands can be really annoying. A lot of times there are enemies right in front of me, and the auto-targeting will lock onto an enemy far in the back or in the air.

- The NPCs in your base are really annoying because they scream and make noises every 0.5 seconds.

Things I want to see/could be better:

- A "Sort to nearby chests" button. It takes a long time to put everything into chests after coming back from a loot trip.

- Expanded skill tree.

- Base raids + NPCs defending the base.

- More interesting loot/rewards for clearing long dungeons/camps.

- Mounts! The map is so damn big, we need some kind of mounts. No flying mounts though, please — that would ruin exploring completely.

- Modding support. Just let people mod the game. It makes every game better, especially these types of survival games.

- Give people more control over how they want to play. I complained about stamina already, but I wouldn’t have done that if I had the ability to just turn off stamina.

Overall: I enjoy the game a lot and know it’s going to do well. I’m not too harsh with my criticism because I know it’s still an Early Access game in the end.

Today, a game with a building system that feels like Minecraft + Valheim + Conan Exiles all in one. Think of it as Minecraft, but grown up. We’re talking about Enshrouded, a co-op survival action RPG developed and released by Keen Games GmbH.

[h1] Chicken Jockey [/h1]
I used to play a lot of Minecraft. First on PC and later on console. That game consumed a lot of my time. I loved Minecraft because of the building, the creativity, and the freedom. I think that’s why I really enjoyed Enshrouded too. It’s definitely not a Minecraft clone, because this game is much more realistic (graphics) and way more RPG-like.

[h1] Story [/h1]
In Enshrouded, you play as a Flameborn, one of the last survivors of your people. You wake up in a world threatened by a dangerous, mysterious mist. You head out to explore this world, defeat enemies, and slowly rebuild the old kingdom. You can create huge structures, upgrade your gear, and play together with others, up to 16 players at once.

[h1] Early Access [/h1]
We have to keep in mind that Enshrouded is still in Early Access. The developers say they want to continue building the game together with the community. They want to actively listen to feedback and use it to add improvements and new content.

The game is not finished yet and will get more biomes, enemies, locations, crafting materials, recipes, gear, skills, and more building and decoration options when it fully releases. They say the current Early Access version is already complete at its core and offers plenty of fun, but will continue to expand. The price will go up after Early Access, so keep that in mind if you’re unsure whether to buy it now!

[h1] Gameplay [/h1]
While exploring the world, you’ll search through ruins, wander the wilderness, and try to become stronger along the way. Your goal is to bring the land back to life. You do this by surviving and building. Build structures, work out every detail, and place NPCs who unlock new workstations and better gear. The Shroud has created deadly bosses and corrupted factions, and it’s your job to fight them. When I first launched the game, it immediately felt good. I quickly got the hang of the basic mechanics and started exploring the world. During combat, I noticed that dodging is super important. I built my own settlement and crafted all kinds of different items.

It really felt like playing Minecraft again, but in a more modern style. I did immediately notice that it’s an Early Access game, but I think you should look past that a bit and give the game a chance. I found the building system enjoyable and pretty easy to understand. It’s important to dodge properly during fights and use powerful abilities and spells so you can shape your own combat style as a Mage, Ranger, or Warrior. Without gear, you’re nothing, so craft and upgrade legendary weapons and armor. Expand your skills and make sure you master them!

[h1] Variety and issues [/h1]
You’ll quickly notice that the game is a mix of fighting, exploring, building, and gathering. That’s why I think it fits really well with players who enjoy survival + RPG. And it’s super cool that the game has co-op, without forcing it. But I did have one moment where I thought: I’m closing the game and uninstalling it immediately. I was peacefully cooking my meat, no enemies anywhere. Out of nowhere, a wolf spawned in and started attacking me. Because of that, I respawned behind the fire, inside the fireplace. I was stuck, and the fire (and the wolf) killed me again, making it impossible to ever get my loot back.

[h1] Conclusion [/h1]
Survival felt a bit too easy, and I really missed enemy variety. Combat became repetitive fairly quickly since it’s mostly a simple click-and-dodge loop. After a few hours, I started feeling “done,” even though the game itself wasn’t. I just didn’t feel encouraged to keep going.

Early Access is definitely noticeable, especially in frustrating moments like when a wolf suddenly spawned beside me and caused me to lose my loot permanently. Still, the core of the game is strong. The mix of building, exploring, fighting, and gathering works well, and for players who enjoy survival + RPG, this game definitely has potential. I played solo, and with co-op your sessions can easily become more fun and much longer. And since it’s still growing, there’s plenty of room for it to become something really good.

Lock-on controls are clunky and confusing, requiring two buttons to switch targets, which ruins flow during fights. Enemies kill you in seconds while your own attacks feel delayed and unresponsive. It doesn’t feel like skill-based combat—it feels random and janky. The world and building look great, but none of that matters when just fighting basic enemies feels like wrestling the controls. Please focus on fixing combat responsiveness, hit detection, and movement physics before adding new content.

Overall this is an amazing game - almost everything is executed perfectly, from base building, to farming, to exploration, to collectables, to gorgeous and plentiful armor sets.

There are hundreds of quests, each with a story, that all add to an exceptionally well done world building full of lore and intrigue and drama in an age long past. A bit sad and gloomy, but enjoyable and a treat to go through and read about.

The base feels lively and comfy due to both the amazing building & decoration capabilities and the NPCs you can rescue and... er... adopt(?) I guess, that roam around you base if you let them.

Where it still needs improvement is the combat, which, imo, is the weakest part of the game.
While melee is at least passable, with the caveat that dodges have no iframes (really, really bad choice), and blocking/parries are jank as hell and the timings are atrocious, and finally that melee itself has no inherent "combo" moves at all (you can spec into a couple, but no heavy/light attack or after-parry repostes for example).

Magic is absolute garbage. Literal trash on fire. The staff is NOT a combat weapon, it is a "stand as far back as possible and lob spells until all is dead" tool of disjointed, boring destruction. You cannot parry or block with the staff, and you cannot bonk with the staff.
Wands are somehow worse. The staff at least has SOME oompf (fireballs go boom), but the wands are like pissing on the enemy and somehow they die. No stagger on hit, annoying auto-lock-on that I wish was toggle-able, and, cherry on cake, neither wands nor staves can do any sort of finisher or combo moves.

Honestly magic feels like you become this glorified turret. Your only button is Left Click. No combos with jumps or dodges or whatever, just left click at enemy and watch hp bar go down.

Combat needs a total rework - keep the talents like jump-smash and the dodge-attack, but give all weapons a lot more moves, and magic, especially, a lot more flexibility and just stuff to do with.

Overall, a 6/10 game, mainly because one of the core pillars is depressingly badly implemented at the moment.

Now, some might say "but a 6/10 should be recommended!" - to this I say "No, not yet. When they rework combat, add more enemy variety, and make blocking, dodging, and magic not suck phalluses, then I'll change it to positive and give the game a 9/10".

I eagerly await a ton of bug-fixes, performance improvements and a combat rework, these Devs appear to be competent and listening, so I'm cautiously hopeful.

I want to be more fair as to just how bad combat is:

Enemies, even the weakest ones, always stagger you on hit. 2+ enemies can effectively stunlock you... however YOU cannot stunlock THEM. In fact, no weapon, regardless of size or speed, staggers enemies AT ALL. This completely breaks the flow of combat, since you have to spam block/parry mid-attack since the enemy doesn't care it was just whacked with a huge 2h hammer in the face.

3. Old saves/worlds corruption after new updates. Would you like to spend time creating an interesting base for yourself? You can do this, but expect corruption after a new big update. They constantly change the old world. So for example, if you choose to make a home in the 2nd zone, if they change the world in that place, where you are building is safe (you have a protected area) but the things around your base will change. I'm talking about new terrains levels, new hills and mountains appearing. I spent this year creating an interesting base around the terrain I had, but with the last 2-3 updates, the world around my base became warped. New terrain levels outside my base, new mountains. I created a wall, with a gate on a road that was put there by the developers, last update moved the road, and now in front of my gate I have a huge hills. Now the base doesn't make any sense. 0/10

4. Materials/resources grind. This is wack...even tho you can increase the loot amount from the world settings, you will still find yourself in a constant material grind. You can't make automated farms or anything like that like in minecraft for example, therefore you need to do this yourself. a) Bulding. Building is quite fun at start. You can create some nice looking houses and stuff. However, it's repetitive and boring after some time. a) Pets. Pets are nice, but pointless. They are nice to have around your house and they give you a buff. You have a total of 6 pets but all of them give the same small buff to HP. Most of the time they will get stuck in different places and you will have to pick them up and put them back down just so you can see them running around. 4/10

If you add fences (decorations) or just a thin wall, and put their bed next to it, when they wake up from their bed they will have a chance of spawning outside their pen, therefore not having access to food and not producing what they produce. I feel this needs to be improved as this bug has been around since i started playing. 6/10 just because they give useful stuff.

7. NPCs. You have NPCs. Most of them are useless. They just walk around your base, doing nothing, not working, not doing anything, maybe sitting on a bench/chair from time to time. Most of the time you will see them walking into a wall. So if you want to have a village/castle or anything like that and make it feel alive, it will feel alive but a little bit. (maybe i haven't discovered the way to make them work but I feel like I should have by now or at least being a quest in the game that teaches you how to put them to work.) 5/10 just because of the useful NPCs and workbenches that are vital to your gameplay and progression.

Enshrouded is an amazing game for exploration and for those with that creative talent for town and city building. You can make insanely pretty things in this game. If you are easily gripped by seeing amazing sights and things- and enjoy just simply wandering about with a healthy spice of being menaced by things far above you in level, this is a game you might enjoy. That comes at a caveat. 

Combat. 

Simply put if you don't mind basic combat systems that become VERY samey and never truly improve- or have much beyond the basic combos, I would snatch this game up on a sale. Otherwise stay away (ESPECIALLY if you enjoy melee combat that actually improves over time). 

Without spoiling to much of what you fight in terms of bosses- the combat in this game left me with much to be desired. I've made a character for each archetype, and I mean EACH - and found all of them wanting barring the simplest one, archer- and the mage. (NOT warlock - the wand users)

The skill tree is deceptive. It is EXPANSIVE with some cool ass passives littered through it but within that giant alluring mess are keystone abilities that basically make melee combat have combos and moves that actually make combat NOT feel like a snorefest. I find it very lazy to have all basic moves like a riposte on parry or a dodge attack or jump slam attack something I need to spend skill points on. They have had 'skill tree rework' and 'combat rework' on their roadmap for two years and every year I come back hopeful just to see all theyve done is take more garbage onto the tree. 

Wands skill tree is still pretty iffy considering wands are in a very awful place with the targetting system. Mages and healers get the world as their oyster- and all melee get a gem system you cant even touch at the start of the game thanks to rarity restriction and the gem forge restrictions that lead you into the shroud. 

Now on to bosses. Bosses are. Very interesting. They lack a creative touch that makes them a boss players will go, 'wow remember that epic fight?', except you can tell they want you to have that experience just based on map build up and scenery alone. 

The city boss and mountain peak boss both have this flaw of being extremely frustrating- but i find the mountain peak boss to truly be an affront to game design. If you are a solo melee player, you will struggle - and most likely die on your first attempt with how poorly telegraphed some of its attacks are. You will be forced to bring a bow. The entire thing just kind of reeks- ill be real. The first 4 minutes felt awesome, but then all that hype gurgles down the drain when it yanks you out of immersion with some of its 'mechanics'. I wont spoil any more then that since if people DO get it, they can at least be surprised, since it was actually quite cool to do in the beginning. 

Adding the greatsword was an INTERESTING step- but one I think doesnt actually prove they plan on fleshing out the combat. I like to hope that maybe they are simply rushing to finish all the areas and exploration before making melee combat not feel like guff but... well. I'm not too hopeful. If you are big into the unga bunga and want some layers to your melee- stay away from this game. Save yourself the frustration - or conform to doing a hybrid, or grab it if you have 3+ friends willing to join you to soften the numbing boredom.

If you are interested in this game, read this first. This game has had issues since day one, and has developed more issues since I first played it almost a year ago.

To begin with, there is an issue with the way the game manages its files where downloading a 7mb update or replacing a single corrupt file will take just about as long as a fresh install. Some people on the forums say this is because all the game files are archived (bundled together), so the files have to be un and re-archived every single time.

Next major issue, "compiling shaders". Once you have downloaded and updated the game you are good to play right? Wrong, after the ridiculously long update process, you will then launch the game to either an initially black or incredibly low res title screen (that takes a good while to render) with a little loading icon in the corner of the screen warning you that it is 'compiling shaders' and that you should wait for it to finish before playing the game. After waiting ANOTHER HOUR for the shaders to compile, I finally get in game and... you guessed it, more issues.

Next, the game seems to unload any assets that aren't on the screen for more than 30 seconds. You open your bag, give it some time to load the icons for all the items you have. Close you bag for awhile and reopen it again, same thing! This also goes for weapons. If you use a wand, it will take several attacks before it looks like you are visually attacking. Stop attacking for a minute, and once again there is no visual indicator; wait some more. Similarly, the 'fast travel is just as bad'. Fast travel back to your base and you will be stuck on a black loading screen for another couple of minutes.

Honestly, I have never played a game that left me this frustrated and made me feel like I wasted so much time. When I first played this game, I was able to overlook some of the issues, but following an update in the summer, the game was unplayable. I decided to wait it out until the next update, which just came out, and all these issues still persist. I would recommend waiting until the developers directly address the issues of update times and compiling shaders before even considering to buy this game (it has been a year). As it is, save yourself your money, time, and frustration.

I'm constantly amazed by the building in this game. It's essentially voxel, and it's really fun. 

The crafting system isn't anything new; but it works.

The quests are basically all fetch quests, but it's good enough to get you to explore the world.

The combat, in my opinion, is where Enshrouded completely fails. Sure, you can spend a lot of time building, but eventually you'll want different building materials. To get those, you'll have to engage in the game's combat. There's no "creative mode" either. The majority of Enshrouded's progression revolves around the combat.

The combat is pretty simple but I thought parries and dodge-rolling would be good enough. I was wrong. There are no i-frames at all. No i-frames when dodge rolling, no i-frames on merciless attack (the attack after stance-break). Dodge-rolling is meant to create space between enemies not dodge attacks. I guess there are people who like this, but I found it extremely frustrating especially since you have to engage with the combat to progress with the game. Combat is much less about learning enemy attacks and much more about having the right gear and kiting.

The stamina system is probably my least favorite thing. Even with the fully rested buff, it feels like stamina takes forever to recharge. Stamina in combat can make sense; it slows the player down and / or prevents them from spamming dodge (which doesn't make sense here because dodging doesn't have i-frames). Swinging your weapon doesn't take stamina, which is great, but using any tool (pickaxe, axe, etc) *does* take stamina. Especially in the early game, it feels like you spend more of your time waiting for your stamina to recharge instead of digging. Every other use of stamina is fine, but why does mining resources take stamina? 

TLDR: The game feels *really close* to a good game, but right now it's really slow and frustrating. Here's what I would change:
- put some i-frames in the combat.
- remove stamina cost from mining / digging.
- add creative mode (inf blocks, no stamina, flying, etc.)

I'd recommend this game if they added creative mode; the building is *that* good.
